projects.title: My Art
projects.card-description: Fine art, sketches, web comics, and more.
projects.description:
I've been making art for most my life. My favorite mediums have been pencil and paper, digital art, and more recently, acrylic painting and ceramics.

This is an evolving selection of my favorite pieces. Click on each image for more information.

projects.title: Brain AR
projects.card-description: Developed AR app for the Yale School of Medicine's core curriculum.
projects.description:
In 2018-19, I worked as a student developer for the Yale School of Medicine, under Professor Michael Schwartz and Gary Leydon. I developed an application for first-year medical students, where a brain could be placed in 3D space and broken into subgroups. It was used in Intro to Neurobiology courses in the School of Medicine curriculum.

The project was part of Blended Reality, a collaboration between Yale and HP. A brief overview of the work can be found here.

projects.title: AIIM
projects.card-description: Experimental interactive long-form fiction about robots, group chats, and the end of the world.
projects.description:
AIIM (Artificial Intelligence Instant Messenger) is a project conceived in Spring 2018 and finished at the end of 2019. The best way to describe it is an experimental interactive long form fiction piece about four AI in the far future, and the only way to really understand it is to jump right in.

AIIM was truly a labor of love, and I'm still really proud of what it turned into and what it taught me. There's a small TV Tropes page for it as well.

projects.title: Ranger VR
projects.card-description: Implemented VR functionality into a NASA-internal visual engine. Internship project from summer 2018 at JPL.
projects.description:
I interned at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory during Summer 2018, where I worked on implementing a VR mode into a NASA-internal visual engine called Ranger.

With our final application, users were able to explore an immersive and to-scale solar system via a web browser. Our work contributed to the mission of providing engaging and accessible science education for all.

A demo of my prototype at the end of the summer is available here.

projects.title: Synesthetic Soundtrack
projects.card-description: Defensive publication based on technical explorations I did on a prototyping team at Google, Summer 2019.
projects.description:
In the Summer of 2019, I was an intern on the Google Daydream Boosts team, prototying AR technology for teams across the company. One of the few disclosable items I took away that summer was a Defensive Publication of an experiemental AR application for smart wearables, which uses computer vision to create personalized sonic landscapes.

You can find this publication at the Technical Disclosure Commons.

projects.title: Moiré
projects.card-description: Kinetic sculptures that induce dynamic optical illusions. Art installation built for & funded by one of Yale's residential colleges.
projects.description:
Moiré is a series of kinetic sculptures I built as an art installation in Spring 2019, funded by a Creative and Performing Arts grant from Yale University.

Inspired by the work of artists such as Danny Rozin, I wanted to create a surprising and dynamic work of art while building skills such as laser printing, arduino programming, and more.

I wrote in-depth about my inspiration, process, and takeaways in this Medium article, so I highly recommend reading that as well!

projects.title: Certainty
projects.card-description: Science fiction novelette published in the September 2020 issue of Clarkesworld.
projects.description:
"Certainity" is my first science fiction novelette, published in the September 2020 issue of Clarkesworld Magazine.

It's a story that explores memory and objectivity, and questions what loss and love mean in the face of a fully known universe.

You can read it online free, or listen to it as a podcast here.

projects.title: Our Bodies Are Art
projects.card-description: An interactive examination of evolving female beauty standards through machine learning, computer vision, and classical art.
projects.description:
Our Bodies Are Art is an interactive application that allows users to find and learn about pieces that match their own body type via computer vision and machine learning.

I created this project to explore and deconstruct historical female beauty standards through the lens of classical art. It was built using the TensorFlow.js library BodyPix, and is available online for anyone to use.

It was done as my Senior Project for completion of my computer science degree under Professor Julie Dorsey in the Fall of 2021. The final report can be read here.

projects.title: 55 Plaque
projects.card-description: Science fiction novelette published in the March 2021 issue of Clarkesworld.
projects.description:
"55 Plaque" is a novelette published in the March 2021 issue of Clarkesworld Magazine, and my second published story.

It's a story about extraterrestial communication, the limits of our scientific system, how religion fortifies and distorts our most fundamental desires, and how we survive through our children.

You can read it online free, or listen to it as a podcast.

projects.title: Turn In Your Pset
projects.card-description: A short (~5 min) interactive fiction piece about graduating during a pandemic.
projects.description:
Turn in Your Pset is a small interactive story I wrote in my last semester of college, released in April 2021. It takes about five minutes to play in total.

I made thie piece to explore a lot of topics relevant to my life at the time: to explore anxieties about growing up, ruminate on all the imperfect ways we remember history, and of course, reflect on the state of affairs in early 2021.

It features writing, art, and programming done by me in Godot Engine and music by my friend, Michael Chang.

You can play it online at itch.io!

projects.title: Your Brother's Touchstone
projects.card-description: Science fiction short story published in Luna Station Quarterly Magazine, September 2021.
projects.description:
"Your Brother's Touchstone" is a short story published in issue #47 of Luna Station Quarterly, a speculative fiction magazine for women-identified writers.

It follows two Korean-American siblings, who must learn to depend on each other when caught in a mystery that bends space and time. It is my third published story.

You can read it online free, or buy a digital copy here.

You can also read an author interview with me!

projects.title: Little Life Update
projects.card-description: Experimental comic about social media immortality.
projects.description:
"Little Life Update" is an interactive web comic I made during my first semester at ITP, for the class Experiential Comics with Tony Patrick. It's my examination of social media and the ghosts it can induce.

The comic is best experienced on mobile, but works great on desktop too.
projects.image_alt: Sample image from Little Life Update comic

projects.title: Everything Not Saved
projects.card-description: Interactive fiction game about cleaning out your bedroom.
projects.description:
"Everything Not Saved" is a short game about cleaning the desk of your childhood bedroom. It was built in a few weeks with Unity and using real items from my childhood bedroom, scanned with Polycam.

It's hosted on Itch.io, where you can read my project statement and experience it for yourself!
projects.image_alt: Cover for Everything Not Saved game

projects.title: Sound Garden Playground
projects.card-description: A music-making interactive designed for accessible musical collaboration
projects.description:
"Sound Garden Playground" is a interactive, collaborative project that creates a semi-structured music-making environment, encouraging visitors to play within an ephemeral looping format with a subset of tones. It is designed to spark spontaneous collaboration and connection, and lower the barrier to engaging in collaborative musical experimentation.

Made in collaboration with Alexandra Palocz for the ITP class Cabinets of Wonder, I was in charge of programming the visual interface in Unity, as well as making the art assets you see in game. The project was showcased in the ITP Spring Show 2023

projects.title: Click
projects.card-description: A dazzling puzzle game with a deceptively simple premise: to align items perfectly.
projects.description:
"Click" is a browser-based game where players complete sets of rapid, dynamic, and vibrant puzzles that build in complexity and scale.

Click can be played most simply using a mouse or trackpad, but takes on a new dimension with a second mode augmented by computer vision. In this mode, players use the position hands to guide puzzle pieces, enhancing the game's natural challenge.

Made with javascript for the ITP class Web Art as Site, and shown in the ITP Spring Show 2023, this game is available on the web for everyone to try.

about.title: About
about.description:
Isabel Lee is a creative technologist, writer, and artist based in Brooklyn.

Currently, Isabel works as a game engineer at Double Loop Games. She is also a Master's candidate at NYU's Interactive Telecommunications Program, and graduated with a degree in Computer Science from Yale University. Her previous experiences inclulde work at Google and NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory.
